classifications.note: Lorentz force: $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$; Magnitude: $F_B = |q|vB\sin\theta$; Direction: right-hand rule for positive q, reverse for negative; Units: 1 N = 1 C·m/s·T

principles.statement: The Lorentz force law follows fundamental principles: Vector Equation: $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$; Cross product ensures perpendicular force. Magnitude Calculation: $F_B = |q|vB\sin\theta$; $\theta$ = angle between $\vec{v}$ and $\vec{B}$; Maximum when $\theta = 90^\circ$ ($\sin\theta = 1$); Zero when $\theta = 0^\circ$ or $180^\circ$ ($\sin\theta = 0$). Direction Determination: Right-hand rule: point fingers in $\vec{v}$ direction, curl toward $\vec{B}$, thumb gives force direction for positive q; Negative q: reverse direction; Alternative: $\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$ gives direction for positive charge. Work-Energy Theorem: Magnetic force does no work: $\vec{F}_B \cdot \vec{v} = 0$ (always perpendicular); Changes direction but not speed; Kinetic energy constant. Charge Dependence: Positive charges: follow right-hand rule directly; Negative charges: force direction reversed; Same magnitude for same |q|. Special Cases: $\vec{v} \parallel \vec{B}$: $F_B = 0$, straight-line motion; $\vec{v} \perp \vec{B}$: $F_B = |q|vB$, circular motion; General angle: helical motion. Unit Analysis: 1 tesla = 1 N/(A·m) = 1 N·s/(C·m); 1 N = 1 C·m/s·T.
principles.application: Calculate magnetic force magnitude for given conditions. Determine force direction using right-hand rules. Analyze force for different charge types. Solve problems with various velocity-field angles. Verify force perpendicularity. Apply Lorentz force law systematically.
principles.example: Calculate force on electron moving in magnetic field. Determine force direction for given scenario. Analyze force for parallel vs perpendicular motion. Solve for unknown variable in force equation.
principles.analogy: Like a string tension in circular motion - the magnetic force always pulls perpendicular to the motion, changing direction but not speed, similar to how a string constrains a ball in circular motion without speeding it up or slowing it down

worked_examples.title: Basic Force Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A proton ($q = +1.6 \times 10^{-19}$ C) moves at $2 \times 10^6$ m/s perpendicular to a 0.5 T magnetic field. Calculate the magnetic force magnitude and describe its direction.

step_by_step.explanation: Right-hand rule: $\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$ gives direction perpendicular to both
Force = $1.6 \times 10^{-13}$ N perpendicular to both velocity and field

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic force = $1.6 \times 10^{-13}$ N; Direction perpendicular to both velocity and magnetic field vectors

worked_examples.title: Force Direction Analysis
worked_examples.problem: An electron moves east in a magnetic field directed north. Determine the direction of the magnetic force.

step_by_step.step: Apply right-hand rule for positive charge
step_by_step.explanation: Fingers east, curl toward north → thumb points upward
Electron has negative charge, so reverse direction
Force direction = downward (opposite to right-hand rule result)
Force is perpendicular to both east (velocity) and north (field)

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic force direction = downward; Perpendicular to both eastward velocity and northward field

sections.section_title: 2. Charged Particle Motion in Magnetic Fields
sections.introduction: Analyzing the trajectories of charged particles in magnetic fields, including circular motion, helical paths, and applications to particle control and measurement.

key_concept.definition: Circular motion, Cyclotron motion, Helical paths, Radius of curvature, Cyclotron frequency, Magnetic confinement
key_concept.context: Charged particles moving perpendicular to uniform magnetic fields follow circular paths due to the constant-magnitude perpendicular magnetic force, while particles with velocity components both perpendicular and parallel to the field trace helical trajectories.

image.caption: Charged particle trajectories in magnetic fields

classifications.value: Classification based on velocity orientation relative to magnetic field
characteristics: Radius depends on momentum and charge
classifications.behavior: The magnetic force acts as a centripetal force that constrains charged particles to specific curved paths, with the curvature radius proportional to momentum and inversely proportional to field strength and charge

examples.explanation: Particles moving perpendicular to uniform magnetic field follow circular paths

image.caption: Circular motion of charged particles in uniform B field

examples.explanation: Particles with both perpendicular and parallel velocity components trace helical paths

classifications.note: Circular motion: $F_B = \frac{mv^2}{r}$ provides centripetal force; Radius: $r = \frac{mv}{|q|B}$; Cyclotron frequency: $f = \frac{|q|B}{2\pi m}$; Period: $T = \frac{2\pi m}{|q|B}$; Helical motion: circular + linear components

principles.principle: Charged Particle Motion in Magnetic Fields
principles.statement: Charged particle motion follows specific patterns: Circular Motion ( $\vec{v} \perp \vec{B}$ ): Magnetic force provides centripetal acceleration: $|q|vB = \frac{mv^2}{r}$; Radius: $r = \frac{mv}{|q|B}$; Angular frequency: $\omega = \frac{|q|B}{m}$; Period: $T = \frac{2\pi m}{|q|B}$ (independent of v). Helical Motion ( $\vec{v}$ at angle to $\vec{B}$ ): Perpendicular component: circular motion; Parallel component: uniform motion; Result: helical path; Pitch: $p = v_{\parallel}T = \frac{2\pi mv_{\parallel}}{|q|B}$. Straight-Line Motion ( $\vec{v} \parallel \vec{B}$ ): $F_B = 0$, no magnetic force; Continues with constant velocity. Energy Considerations: Magnetic force does no work; Kinetic energy constant; Speed constant; Direction changes. Mass Spectrometry: Particles with same charge but different mass; Different radii in same B field; $r \propto m$ for fixed q, v, B. Particle Confinement: Magnetic bottles; Tokamak fusion devices; Van Allen radiation belts; Cyclotrons and synchrotrons. Relativistic Effects: At high speeds, mass increases; Radius increases for same momentum; $r = \frac{p}{|q|B}$ where $p = \gamma mv$.
principles.application: Calculate radius of circular motion in magnetic fields. Determine cyclotron frequency and period. Analyze helical trajectories and pitch. Solve particle identification problems. Design magnetic confinement systems. Apply motion principles to practical devices.
principles.example: Calculate electron radius in given B field. Determine cyclotron frequency for proton. Analyze particle separation in mass spectrometer. Design magnetic bottle configuration.
principles.analogy: Like a ball on a string swung in a circle - the string tension (magnetic force) always pulls toward the center, maintaining circular motion at constant speed, with a longer string (larger radius) needed for faster or heavier balls

worked_examples.title: Mass Spectrometer Analysis
worked_examples.problem: In a mass spectrometer, singly ionized atoms of carbon-12 and carbon-13 ($^{12}C^+$ and $^{13}C^+$) are accelerated through the same voltage and enter a 0.5 T magnetic field. Compare their path radii. ($m_{12} = 1.993 \times 10^{-26}$ kg, $m_{13} = 2.159 \times 10^{-26}$ kg)

Carbon-13 path radius is 4.1% larger than carbon-12

sections.introduction: Exploring practical applications of magnetic forces on moving charges, analyzing combined electric and magnetic fields, and examining advanced particle control techniques.

key_concept.definition: Velocity selector, Mass spectrometer, Cyclotron, Hall effect, Magnetic confinement, Lorentz force in combined fields
key_concept.context: Magnetic forces on moving charges enable numerous practical applications including particle selection, mass measurement, acceleration, and confinement, often using combined electric and magnetic fields for precise control.

classifications.value: Classification based on application principle and device type
characteristics: Velocity selectors: crossed E and B fields
Cathode ray tubes: electron beam control
classifications.behavior: Different applications exploit specific aspects of magnetic force behavior: velocity selectors use balanced forces, mass spectrometers use mass-dependent curvature, cyclotrons use constant-frequency acceleration, and Hall effect uses transverse charge separation

examples.explanation: Crossed electric and magnetic fields selecting particles by velocity

image.caption: Velocity selector using crossed E and B fields

examples.explanation: Circular particle accelerator using magnetic confinement

classifications.note: Velocity selector: $v = E/B$ for straight trajectory; Mass spectrometer: $m = \frac{qB^2r^2}{2V}$; Cyclotron: $f = \frac{qB}{2\pi m}$; Hall effect: $V_H = \frac{IB}{nqt}$; Applications: research, medicine, industry

principles.statement: Magnetic force applications employ specific principles: Velocity Selector: Crossed E and B fields ($\vec{E} \perp \vec{B}$); Electric force: $F_E = qE$; Magnetic force: $F_B = qvB$; Balanced when $qE = qvB$ → $v = E/B$; Only particles with this velocity pass undeflected. Mass Spectrometer: Particles accelerated by electric field; Velocity selection (optional); Magnetic field bends trajectories; Radius: $r = \frac{mv}{qB}$; Mass measurement: $m = \frac{qB^2r^2}{2V}$. Cyclotron: Constant magnetic field; Alternating electric field; Synchronized with cyclotron frequency: $f = \frac{qB}{2\pi m}$; Particles spiral outward with increasing energy. Hall Effect: Current in magnetic field; Charge carriers deflected; Transverse voltage develops; Hall voltage: $V_H = \frac{IB}{nqt}$; Determines charge carrier density and sign. Magnetic Confinement: Magnetic bottles for plasma; Tokamaks for fusion; Van Allen belts natural confinement; Minimum-B configurations. Combined Lorentz Force: Total force: $\vec{F} = q\vec{E} + q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$; Electric field: accelerates, does work; Magnetic field: deflects, no work. Practical Devices: CRT displays; Particle accelerators; Mass spectrometers; Hall probes; Fusion reactors.
principles.application: Design velocity selectors for specific particle velocities. Analyze mass spectrometer operation. Calculate cyclotron parameters. Solve Hall effect problems. Design magnetic confinement systems. Apply combined field concepts to practical devices.
principles.example: Design velocity selector for given particle velocity. Calculate mass from spectrometer data. Determine cyclotron frequency for specific particles. Analyze Hall voltage measurements.
principles.analogy: Like a customs checkpoint - the velocity selector acts like a speed filter letting only certain speeds through, the mass spectrometer like sorting by weight, and the cyclotron like a circular racetrack where particles get repeated boosts each lap

worked_examples.title: Velocity Selector Design
worked_examples.problem: Design a velocity selector to pass protons with velocity $1 \times 10^6$ m/s. The magnetic field is 0.1 T. Determine the required electric field strength and orientation.

step_by_step.explanation: $\vec{E}$ and $\vec{B}$ must be perpendicular; $\vec{E} \times \vec{B}$ direction gives force balance
$F_E = qE$ opposite to $F_B = qvB$ when properly oriented
Use parallel plates for E field, perpendicular magnets for B field

worked_examples.final_answer: Required electric field = $1 \times 10^5$ V/m; E and B fields must be perpendicular and properly oriented for force cancellation

worked_examples.title: Hall Effect Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A copper strip 1 mm thick and 2 cm wide carries 10 A current in a 1 T magnetic field perpendicular to the strip. The Hall voltage measures 0.5 μV. Calculate the charge carrier density. (q = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C)
worked_examples.final_answer: Charge carrier density = $1.25 \times 10^{29}$ carriers/m³; Typical for copper (8.5 × 10²⁸ electrons/m³)

common_misconceptions: Thinking magnetic force can speed up or slow down charges
Believing magnetic fields can do work on moving charges
Assuming force direction doesn't depend on charge sign
Thinking all charged particles move in circles in magnetic fields
Believing magnetic force depends on the frame of reference
Assuming magnetic fields affect stationary charges
Thinking the right-hand rule is arbitrary rather than based on cross products
real_world_applications: Cathode ray tubes in old displays
summary: The magnetic force on a moving charge follows the Lorentz force law $\vec{F}_B = q\vec{v} \times \vec{B}$, producing a force perpendicular to both velocity and magnetic field vectors. The force magnitude is $F_B = |q|vB\sin\theta$, maximum when velocity is perpendicular to the field and zero when parallel. Charged particles in uniform magnetic fields exhibit characteristic motions: circular paths when $\vec{v} \perp \vec{B}$ with radius $r = \frac{mv}{|q|B}$ and cyclotron frequency $f = \frac{|q|B}{2\pi m}$, helical paths when velocity has both perpendicular and parallel components, and straight-line motion when $\vec{v} \parallel \vec{B}$. Practical applications include velocity selectors (using crossed E and B fields where $v = E/B$), mass spectrometers (separating particles by mass-to-charge ratio), cyclotrons (particle accelerators using constant magnetic fields), and Hall effect devices (measuring charge carrier properties). The magnetic force does no work, changing only the direction of motion while conserving kinetic energy.
